Speaker.hpid: Mr. Bell Mr. Bell
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the reason for the delay in commencing work on a school (details supplied) in County Louth; if there have been any changes made or proposed in the original plan as submitted to his Department; the reasons for any such change; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: The delay referred to by the Deputy was caused by the necessity to enlarge the extension planned at the school to take account of the closure of St. Michael's Secondary School, Omeath at the end of this school year. Construction of the extension is under way since July 1985 and is scheduled to be completed by the end of this year.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Durkan Mr. Durkan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the current position in regard to the provision of an extension and facilities at a school (details supplied) in County Kildare; the places and facilities that are being provided; the remaining planning and development stages that are in the process, and still to be overcome prior to going to contract; and the likely time factor in relation to these remaining stages.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: The current position regarding this project is that the examination of the bills of quantities has very recently been finalised. Architectural planning was based on an enrolment of 350 pupils. The facilities being provided for in those plans are as follows, nine general classrooms, one mechanical drawing room, one science laboratory, one junior metalwork room, one library, general purposes/PE area, ancillary accommodation.

The remaining stages of planning prior to commencement of construction would be the invitation of, and report on, tenders. In the normal way the period that would elapse between the release of a project to tender and the signing of a contract would be in the region of three months.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Durkan Mr. Durkan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education with regard to the proposed extension to the convent primary school in Kilcock, County Kildare; the current position in regard to provision of the extension; when it is expected that the next stage of the planning and development process will be reached; the number of stages that still remain to be processed; the expected time projection in each remaining stage, if there are any difficulties likely to arise to delay the project going to tender; and when this stage will be reached.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: A sketch scheme including costings for the proposed extension to the convent primary school in Kilcock, County Kildare has been prepared and agreement has been reached between my Department and the school authorities on a suitable local contribution. My Department expects in the near future to formally sanction a grant for the scheme. Arrangements will then be made for the preparation of the contract documents, after which the question of inviting tenders for the project will arise. It is not possible to give a time projection for the processing of the various remaining stages, or to say in advance what difficulties are likely to arise.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the procedure used for accounting to the Government, by each State board under his control; and if all of these are in keeping with modern accounting and reporting practices.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: With regard to the bodies of this type for which I am responsible (The Higher Education Authority, The National Council for Educational Awards and the Dublin Institute for Advanced Studies) the annual accounts, after audit by the Comptroller and Auditor General are, together with a copy of his report thereon, presented to the Government prior to being laid before each House of the Oireachtas.

The financial allocations to these institutions each year are determined on the basis of statements setting out estimated expenditure and receipts for the current year and projections for future years submitted in the context of the annual Estimates for the Public Services.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: The meeting referred to by the Deputy between officers of my Department and the authorities of the school referred to took place on 19 March 1986. Speaker.hpid: Mr. Yates Mr. Yates

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the procedures used for accounting to the Government by each State board under his control; and if all of these are in keeping with modern accounting and reporting practices.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: Three statutory bodies for which I have responsibility submit to me their annual accounts audited by the Comptroller and Auditor General, together with an annual report of their activities. These reports are laid before each House of the Oireachtas.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Shift Work Licences.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Keating Mr. Keating
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour if he will state, for each of the past five years, the number of applications for exemption orders under the Conditions of Employment Acts received by him from employers wishing to introduce shift work, indicating in respect of each such application; (1) the firm involved; (2) the number of employees involved; (3) whether they were male or female; (4) the period for which the exemption was sought; (5) whether it is still in force; (6) the nature of the shift sought and (7) whether the application was successful.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: I am assuming that the Deputy is referring to applications for shift work licences under the Conditions of Employment Act, 1936. I regret that the information sought is not available in the details required and that it would take an inordinate amount of time to abstract from the Department's records, involving the redeployment of scarce staff resources from essential duties.

MainHeading.P: A draft order, entitled the Employment Equality (Employment of Women) Order, which was approved by Seanad Éireann on 19 March and now awaits the approval of Dáil Éireann, will bring to an end the existing legal prohibition on the employment of women in industrial nightwork and on Sundays. The removal of the restrictions on the employment of women at night should greatly ease the position in relation to the processing of applications for shift work licences.
